content.description: This would be decent climb were it not broken by a small ledge with a tree but alas. . .  It can be combined with the top part of Gomez the Cat by an easy stepover for a longer more fulfilling variation.   What little there is is pretty great.
content.protection: Hand size piece(s) and you can sling the the tree.  There are no anchors at the very top.
content.location: Climb the appealing but all too short splitter hand crack just right of Gomez the Cat to a ledge with a small but slingable tree on it.  Finish if you want up the mossy corner above or step left into Gomez the Cat crack.  An easy solo too.  Avoid the right arete makes for some fun jamming and may up the grade a little.

content.description:
This is a nice slab climb at a moderate grade.    

  This climbs the face just left of Gomez the Cat. From the ground, mantle onto the stance at a sloping ledge, then move gingerly upward for a couple cruxy moves over a bulge, and head up to a decent rail at the top.   

  Currently this ends straight up, but with little cleaning, a couple more moves could be added by traversing left at the end.
content.location:
This is the cleaned off face right next to Gomez the Cat.  Start mantling onto the obvious, sloping ledge and head virtually straight up.   

  The top can be reached via an easy walk up on the right.

content.description:
This is one of Cape Ann's nicer crack climbs!  

  Gomez the Cat is a little reminiscent of Tin Man but milder being lower angle. It follows a gently widening top to bottom crack that goes from incipient seam to off-size fingers. The bottom of the crack is too thin for gear so friction easily up to a nice stance and place pro. This is a sweet, mellow climb named in memory of a sweet, mellow guy and an ideal first lead. The crux might be the opening mantle.  

  The climb has just recently been cleaned, so the condition will only improve with more use.
content.protection: It is definitely G-rated; however, the tentative (and the short) may benefit from having microcams at the start. Otherwise this will protect well with regular cams in the smaller range. You place them in ascending order as the crack widens. Nut placements are a little trickier given the mostly parallel nature of the crack.2 bolts at the top.Â
content.location:
This is the fairly obvious cleaned off crack nearer the right end of the Pet Slabs, which are not big.  

  The top can be reached easily from the ramp at the right.

content.description: This is the right scrubby face bisected by a crack (Gomez the Cat).  The rock quality is good, but this face was/is thickly buried in a mixture of moss, lichen, and leaves.
